name: Defining-Set Duality for Cyclic Codes (Euclidean)
statement: Let C be a cyclic code of length n over GF(q) with gcd(n, q) = 1 and defining set Z ⊆ Z/nZ. Then C^⊥ is cyclic with Z(C^⊥) = Z/nZ \ (−Z), where −Z = {−i mod n : i ∈ Z}. In particular, C ⊆ C^⊥ iff Z ⊇ Z/nZ \ (−Z), i.e., Z ∪ (−Z) = Z/nZ; fixed points of inversion must be in Z.

name: Mattson–Solomon Transform for Cyclic Codes
statement: Evaluation at the n-th roots of unity α^i diagonalizes cyclic convolution: a cyclic code corresponds to sequences whose spectra vanish on a fixed index set T (the defining set). Factor/zero-set relations can be tracked via these spectra.
source: Algebraic Codes for Data Transmission, Ch. on DFT-based codes
notes: In the semisimple case (gcd(n, q) = 1), each cyclotomic coset is a singleton.

name: Locality via ν-term Dual Checks
statement: If the dual contains a weight-(r+1) vector v(x) = 1 + x^s + ⋯ + x^{rs}, with s = n/(r+1), then locality r follows. In our divisibility formulation, L | h constrains zeros(h) to include zeros(L), which already suffices to derive the contradiction with self-orthogonality.
notes: Beware: v ∈ C^⊥ iff h | v^* (for self-reciprocal v, h | v), not v dividing h.
